properties.name: Desertous South
properties.description: Posted by Gtp   All along the side of the Shoshone Basin Rd. you can find obsidian nodules if you walk along it and pay attention. You can use obsidian for flintknapping and make sharp blades out of the stone to be used for knives, axes, arrowheads, atlatl points, or a number of other different uses. Also within the desertous area is sagebrush, rabbitbrush, mullein (the natives also used this for fish poisoning to kill the fish and catch them afterwards), and a number of other different plants which can be used for edible or medicinal purposes. There is also greasewood which can be used for craft purposes including creating digging sticks for the digging up of plants that have bulbs or deep roots in the ground which cannot easily come out otherwise.

properties.name: Lovely Lonely Apple Trees
properties.description: Posted by GtpFollow 18th or 19th northward (up the hill), past Sabin Elementary on 18th or until the road turns right on 19th. Between these two streets is a grassy clearing and a foot path. On either side of this path are two apple trees! Enjoy!

properties.name: Mercer Slough Park
properties.description: Posted by Gtp 3701 Lake Washington Blvd Se, Bellevue, WAIt\'s the site of an old blueberry farm! Amazing berries, birds and cat-tails. The park entrance is linked with the Bellevue Way park and ride, so it\'s super easy to get a bus from downtown Seattle, or ride a bike across I-90. The perfect early morning glean from July to late August! Also Plum, apple, blackberries, rose-hips!

properties.name: Nettles Farm
properties.description: Posted by GtpAn organic farm island style, visitors are usually welcome!

properties.name: New French Bakery
properties.description: Posted by GtpGood artisan bakery. I\'ve seen their dumpsters appear like multi-hundred pound bread baskets, but things have changed and you have to look past the new, large and covered dumpster to find the one that is still accessable. However, non-profits are able to come in after closing and grab the day old stuff for free (dumpster diving not necessary)

properties.name: OG Local Bread Dumpster -- 16th and NW Marshal. portland
properties.description: Posted by GtpTiny bakery. Bagels and sandwich bread individually wrapped. Locally produced wheat, hearty, whole grain. Best to come after baking and shipping time == perhaps after 4 pm into the night. The dumpster is in the front, within sight of the front of the bakery...I haven\'t had a problem yet. I believe it is a wholesale bakery so there is no server/ barista type situation. good luck! Thanks to M & R for this one!

properties.name: Olive Trees
properties.description: Posted by GtpOlive Trees on Olive Street. What a novelty! Usually there are no remnants of the things that streets are named after. I don\'t know much about processing olives, but from what i understand the trees used to be cultivated here in greater numbers, but the remaining ones are mostly ornamentals that grow on street sides.

properties.name: Potluck in the Park--O'Bryant Square
properties.description: Posted by Gtp SW 9th and Washington at O\'Bryant Square. Free meal served every Sunday of the year, 3pm, rain or shine. If rain, go below to the underground garage. If shining, in the square. Food is donated from local stores, bakeries, companies, etc.

properties.description: Posted by Gtp

properties.name: Rock Creek Canyon/West Side/Wilderness Area
properties.description: Posted by Gtp  As you go down into the Canyon off of Addison Ave., if you go over that small bridge and to that picnic area, you can continue to walk past that area on a paved path which eventually will end as you keep walking in the canyon (you want to walk the side of the canyon that is opposite of the hospital) and eventually you will be on a little trail from there and after that point it is pure wilderness with lots of availabilities for wild edible plants, wild medicinal plants, and crafts. There is a field with stinging nettle, and cattails among other plants which are edible. There is also a field full of wolfsbane (dogbane to you civilized folk) which can be used for cordage, and there is an assortment of other plants which one could find use for, and a whole lot of wildness which can be respected. Please when visiting this area be respectful of it and don\'t treat it like you would treat the main park and litter and destroy it, if you\'re going to do that, just don\'t visit there and everything works out for all of us.
